column1: 1. Step-by-Step navigation is cumbersome. To get back to a particular item to check it or make a correction, you have to page through all steps from the beginning. Some selections aren't retained and must be re-selected each time you go back through (e.g., "does my business carry an inventory?" defaults to "yes" and must be reset each time). Once a value is selected, it should stay until changed by the user. The S-b-S steps should be outlined somewhere so you can jump in where you want to go (e.g., to change an estimated value), just like the Forms view is without having to go back through all the steps.

2. One of the primary reasons I have used TurboTax in the past is that it helps keep me from violating IRS and State regulations. I discovered this year that the NC State software didn't ask a key question about the applicability of the Bailey Exemption to my military retirement pay. This excludes my entire military retirement from NC taxable income. I caught it this year because I questioned the taxable amount. It took me some time to review the law and find the TurboTax button to fix it, but the software never asked me about that particular selection, even though it asked me if I was a veteran. Unfortunately, I missed this error last year and paid the amount TurboTax calculated. The result was a $4,400 overpayment for my 2015 taxes, for which I must now file an amended return and wait up to 20 weeks for my refund.
3. The TurboTax Updater wouldn't update my software. I had to do a manual update. This cost me many hours on the phone with Tech Support (Case #424022607).

4. TurboTax didn't carry my 2015 report numbers forward. Tech Support helped me, but I had to start a new return, which cost me two days of work. I recommend you provide a way to do this after the return is started.

5. My wife and I own a small business and need to itemize expenses for Schedule C. To get the largest deduction in my state (NC), I had to split my business income and expenses equally into two separate businesses, one for me and one for my wife. I had to be sure both businesses were exactly symmetrical. This proved to be extremely cumbersome (See #6 below). I recommend a selection that allows you to enter the data once, then split it, or perhaps fill in one business, then duplicate it and change the Name of the business so things are at least binned symmetrically. Once you split the business, you then need be able to go and correct some things that aren't exactly symmetrical, such as Medicare Part B payments, on a line-by-line basis, but setting the two businesses up should be simplified.

6. Trying to balance the duplicate businesses was made more difficult by the way the step-by-step process labeled the expense categories. The Schedule C Expense Summary lists the expense category names but not the Schedule C line numbers to which the expense category applies. In #5 above, I needed to be sure both business expenses were identical. The only way to see the big picture (the line item to which each expense is charged) to compare them was to print out the Supporting Details, but the printout refers to the line numbers, not the titles. This makes entering the second business numbers in the right order very cumbersome. Hard to use, cumbersome, time waster

After filling out all the personal info, I was continually led to an error screen stating I needed to put in an email address for my contact info. Problem was, there was no way for me to do so. Where it said email there was no block to fill in to the right of it as all other info to fill out had. I was stuck in a vicious circle. I even signed in online, went to my account info, made sure my email was entered there, saved it, and signed out in hopes that that may fix the problem. I tried filing and paying again and still continued to get the same error message. Basically, I was told to put in an email that TurboTax wasn't set up for me to put in therefore I couldn't file and pay for my taxes with my credit card. After spending way too much time and effort trying everything I could think of, I ended up going back and reluctantly choosing to just have the filing fee taken out of my refund which cost me an extra $34.99. I wasn't happy, but had to file so I did so in the hopes that when I contacted TurboTax during the day, they would refund me that forced fee. I should not have to pay that extra fee. I did take pictures of the pages and error messages so it couldn't be blown off as me somehow not following instructions. There was no way for me to type in an email address. So, needless to say, I was extremely frustrated, disappointed, and not happy this time around. There was a glitch in this year's system that was extremely time consuming and frustrating.

It informs me that some residency box needs to be checked that I haven't checked (why was this not taken care of in one of the 5 times I went over the residency section?), and then it gives me two equally indecipherable options (full of negative strings like "not a non-CA non-resident") to choose between. I click on "Forms" to try to figure out what is going on, but I can make no sense of it. With time running out, I cross my fingers that I've checked the correct box: it's impossible to tell. When I return to Easy Step, of course, it makes me start at the beginning of the "File" stage, which adds on another couple minutes of clicking through questions I've already answered.

column1: The last several of these years, I've become self-employed and have been using TurboTax Business edition for my small business...it's better than spending hours with an accountant, but I'm sorry to say, it's nowhere near as solid as the consumer products.

As an example, they have you print, sign and scan a signature page for efile before they do a final check on your return. If the check finds any problems that cause you to change anything, you need to repeat that whole print, sign and scan process again since the page has a summary of your taxes. Little things like that make the product feel like it's fighting against you.
Biggest issue, however, is that the software seems buggy in some spots.

After spending time getting my balance sheet reconciled, I got all the way through my return before the final check stopped me because two numbers from different forms were out of balance. Turns out that reconciling the balance sheet never went back and carried my changes through the rest of my return, and I ended up needing to almost start from scratch.
A few other picky things...
As a Mac user, troubles me that TurboTax Business is only available for Windows...every year, I hold my breath that my 2009 copy of Windows will still run.
The installation process is also pretty cumbersome - it brings in a lot of Microsoft prerequisites, and if you need them, you're in for at least one reboot.

Anyway, I'm sure it's not a big seller for Intuit, but I'd certainly encourage them to put a few more resources into making TurboTax Business as solid as their consumer products. Not as full-featured as the consumer products

Under “Hawaii Forms” choose “Retirement Wks”
Entered in the “Retirement Exclusion Worksheet” under “Pensions/IRAs NOT Taxable to Hawaii”
Form N-11 Line 13 Pensions taxed Federally but not taxed by Hawaii.
If this is not done, the State Taxes owed will increase dramatically. This question was not asked during the questioning process.
Medical Expenses
Turbo Tax did not enter Medical and dental expenses for the State Tax Return.
The State figures the Medical and Dental expenses differently than the Federal Tax Returns.

column1: NPR and Freakonomics both reported on Joseph Bankman, a Stanford professor who attempted to get the state of California to change the way that taxes are filed. If you think about it, they already have most of the info needed to calculate your taxes. To paraphrase the host, if Visa or MasterCard expected you to keep track of your purchases and file every year with all the details to pay your bill, we would all go crazy.

In many other countries, you get a bill from the government, which you are free to alter, and you pay it - no muss, no fuss. If you want to pay someone to go through it, have at it. But these companies, and tax preparers, are siphoning off *billions* of dollars that only add churn to the system.
To make matters worse, Intuit spends millions lobbying Congress to maintain the status quo.
Anyway, check it out for yourself, here:

column2: Waaaaaay too much upselling Look, I get it, intuit has to make a buck, but the constant harassment to upgrade to Deluxe (which I went with) and the various other services on top of that were a bit much. Fast filing, but more money is required at the end I normally use Turbo Tax to file my returns and am typically happy with it. I feel they make things easy to understand and I haven't had any filing issues when using them (knock on wood). This time when I filed I noticed the "optional" Premium portion at the end of filing. I attempted to bypass it, but in order for me to file, I had to click the Premium button. I think that's a little deceptive. Don't make it seem like it's an optional program if it's not. You are required to pay for 3 parts. Premium is mandatory but seemed optional at first.
